review_title: Worked as Web Developer in IT

Since it is a state university, you will get benefit for state employees which will help a lot in travel, car rental, parks, hotel reservations, etc. Also you will get a good work-life balance. Also offers tuition reimbursement up to some extents.
cons: Pay is lower. Growth opportunities are less since people tend to hold on to their jobs.

pros: Warm, inclusive, and supportive culture and high level of professionalism, although I’m sure it varies a little by department.

Adjunct pay is low even though there is a great deal of work in addition to showing up to teach the class. I make about $15/hr for teaching and I have several advanced degrees including a PhD. Working as an adjunct can be very isolating.

It takes months--even years--to move on big projects, the red tape is unbelievable. If you don't like slow-moving jobs, you may not like working here

pros: Great work environment to meet lots of new people as a freshmen. Ability to grow within the department. Flexible schedule.
cons:
Rec Center used to be an enjoyable place to work however in recent years poor management with unnecessary strict rules and harsh punishments have led to no one enjoying their job anymore. Most workers are upset about management and expressed interest in quitting their positions. Here are the following reasons: 

Summer shifts for facilities consists of 7.25 hours of standing with a ten minute break that doesn’t allow you to leave the building to get food. We are not allowed to eat or drink anything but water on shift. If you sit down during your shift you get a write up that leads to termination of employment. 

Another strict rule is not eating in the employee lounge and threaten to take away our privileges of having a microwave in emails. However, step two feet out of the lounge and you are allowed to eat? Does not make sense. 

TVs were turned off for a period of time downstairs because they thought we were distracted by it. Paying patrons asked to have the TV on to watch the news in the morning but we had to refuse. 

Chairs and tables downstairs were removed for a period of time because people sat down and talked to facilities.  

They send emails periodically about new unnecessary rules to threaten us yet not follow through with it a few weeks later.

job_title: Grauduate Research Assistant in Montclair, NJ
pros: Nice pay and useful work. Honestly a really great experience with some really interesting and intelligent people.
cons: I feel like no one is brags about all the good work they do and can honestly have more school spirit.

pros: Great place to work. Great management, and benefits. Pension, etc.
cons: Not much room to grow, old school mentality.

pros: Learn a lot of things that you didn’t know prior
cons: Not enough work sometimes and it makes you look lazy

pros: Our university is in a growth pattern so there are lots of possibilities.  There are some amazing people here really trying to make a difference in a challenging environment.  There are and will be opportunities to do great work in pockets.  Work/Life balance is really good for the most part.  Changes are happening and they can be good as long as people are patient.  Since the staff levels are low, there is opportunity to have your hands in many things.  If you are interested in a challenge and you have enough optimism to think you can make a difference, then this is the place for you.
cons: There is not enough staff to support the growth in student population.  As a union place, there are lots of mediocre work done here.  It's used as a crutch to rationalize a poor work ethic.  Not everyone acts this way but it's pretty rampant.  The pay is not the best so you have to really value the mission.  We do not get 100% of our funding from the state government, yet they get to dictate 100% of the rules.  It is very command and control, micro-managed culture.  There is very little empowerment.  If you happen to get a supervisor who doesn't succumb to this, then you can have a great experience.

pros:

cons:

pros: It’s a good job overall so go for it
cons: there’s a lot of red tape and union shenanigans

pros: Welcoming community and beautiful campus.
cons: Important to choose selective programs

job_title: Associate Director in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Great benefits and working environment
cons: Opportunity for growth is lacking and salaries are low.

review_title: Good environment for research but unacceptable compensation
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Montclair, NJ
pros:
Montclair state has attracted several very good faculty researchers in both mathematics and the sciences, and the student researchers have access to better resources than one might expect from a relatively unknown university. 
The campus is located close to New York City and is right on the train. There is great food in Montclair itself, and downtown Montclair is great.
cons: The pay is shameful. It suggests an utter lack of respect towards the graduate students. 15k a year in the New York metro area is below poverty wage. No worker can perform their best if they don't have enough money for food and rent. Most graduate students can not live without a second job. Look into NJIT, Stevens, and Rutgers first! You can do good work here, but you had better not rely on the income.

job_title: Project Manager in West Nyack, NY
pros: They have a very large and aggressive agenda  for implementing many new systems - seems to be an unlimited tax paid budget.
cons: Don't have the internal corporate culture to implement the massive changes required. Inexperienced leadership to make these changes in a higher ed environment. Relying on consultants with very high turnover. Replaced almost every PM in the last 18 months. Replacing staff, knowledge, and skills. Very little job stability for consultants. You can be gone at any moment. Best people left on their own, saw the writing on the wall. Large internal IT staff who leave at 3-4 o'clock not accountable for major projects.

job_title: Doc Fellow, Adjunct in Montclair Heights, NJ
pros: The people are really nice, and the other student GAs are kind, smart, and easy to get along with. You get to do lots of different types of work (research, journal writing, etc.), and most of the professors are reasonable about what they want. Good campus atmosphere.
cons: There is a lot of inconsistency in what is expected from each GA or doctoral assistant - some work really, really hard, and some hardly at all.  It all depends on who you are assigned to.

review_title: One of the best positions I've ever taken
job_title: Student Web Assistant in Montclair, NJ
pros: Office staff is friendly, professional, and laid back (whenever opportune), you will get the opportunity to interact with a wide variety of people and students from different backgrounds and majors. They are extremely flexible with your schedule as long as you put in your 15 hours/ 4 school days per week AND you complete all tasks within the deadlines issued. You will be given the opportunity to learn about various International Study Abroad trips and countries while you're doing your work.
cons:
School has them located in a small single family house converted into office.
School sets guidelines on what they can pay their student assistants. 
All the student assistants are segmented between 3 floors and it takes a bit of effort to meet and interact with your peers.

review_title: Loved my job and my alma mater.
pros: Learned a lot that was helpful to what I plan to do in the future. My experience was quite valuable to my job hunt now.
cons: The pay could've been better but that's to be expected with a part-time job at a university. Also, if I called in sick, they had me work from home instead so there were absolutely no days off. But I think that helped me in the end.

pros: Great contacts and ability to get to know students and faculty in your department. Workload is not too bad, which gives good time to balance work, classes, and a personal life. Gives Tuition Remission depending on the department and position. Some professors and students you meet are great people to get to know.
cons: Horrible pay, would not be able to survive if you live on your own. Disorganized management: never knew if my supervisor was the professor I TA’d for or my program coordinator. Horrible relationship with my program coordinator, who constantly makes me feel horrible about myself and lowers my self-esteem. Experience probably ranges from program to program, though.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Montclair Heights, NJ
pros: I worked as an adjunct in the MA in Counseling program, and the BA in Family Studies programs.  The atmosphere is great; the students are nice and motivated.  Lots of support from the administration as an adjunct in the Family and Child Studies.
cons: There are not a lot of cons; mostly that parking is a huge problem on campus for everyone, and that adjuncts aren't necessarily given any priority or free passes.

pros: I learned so much there. As a work study student I really got lucky in my position.  Sometimes it was a bit hectic, but most of it was smooth sailing. I would definitely do it again
cons: Not really much cons. I mean parking is forever sucky. The shuttle is also forever sucky. But as for the job it self, maybe more pay would be helpful. But all in all beggars cant be choosers.

review_title: Student Assistance Employment (University Advancement Report Writer)
job_title: University Advancement Report Writer in Montclair, NJ
pros:
The cool thing about "student assistance" employment is that it is not work-study and is thus available to anyone.
Very flexible schedules if you're a student.
Great people to work with.
Resume-builder.
Due to renovations at the time, I was still paid for the hours I would have normally worked.
Independent work with some supervision.
cons:
It's all office work. Not really for people who constantly need to move around.
For University Advancement Report Writers: it requires the ability to write and proofread/edit (as the title suggests).
It's temporary (for the semester only) unless you're work-study or just that great at the job.

pros: The school is in a dynamic and exciting location
cons: The school atmosphere is pretty relaxing, which can also be considered a negative aspect as tenured faculty members are super lazy. Colleagues in my department are alright but they are really old. Well, being old does not mean a bad thing as long as they are motivated to learn and improve teaching skills. Students complain a lot as old faculty members do not even update course materials and cannot even use power point etc.

pros: I made good friends among the staffs I worked for over my 4 years at MSU, and the position taught me valuable conflict resolution and leadership skills. Since there are very few hard-line 'hours' that you have to work - with only the mandatory 4 hours of desk shift, which you get to schedule , and duty nights where you're on call - the position is very flexible to an undergraduate class  and part time work schedule.  There's also free housing.
cons: With the benefit of free housing, you lose your control over where you live, as ResLife places you where they need you. The stipend comes out at roughly $200 biweekly. New RAs make less than RAs returning for additional years, but the increase from 'new' to 'returner' is one time, so you won't get more money on each paycheck for your third year. The department is also becoming very pushy with their 'high education track', trying to get RAs to pursue future careers in Residence Life. This is even to the extend that graduating students who did not pursue degrees in higher education or school counseling psychology in undergraduate cannot advance upward to positions such as 'community director' or 'assistant community director'. Graduate students also can no longer become RAs, as the department decided they want to encourage graduate students to pursue positions like assistant community director or 'office assistant', the latter of which has no residential benefits and a minor increase in pay. Additionally, the semester-long 'in-services' are a headache that are intended to act like 'continuing training' after the week-long summer training ends, but end up being mandatory sessions that indirectly relate to the RA position at best, and are an irrelevant  waste of time at worst. Additionally, all RAs are now required to take a Leadership Psyc course which does not fit into all student's degree requirements, basically forcing a student to pay for the requirement.

pros: It is a great, laidback setting to work in.  I was given plenty of freedom in how I wanted to perform tasks.  Working with professors is great because you are able to pick the minds of experts in each field.
cons: The system for logging hours is prehistoric and overly bureaucratic.   Hours must be logged on very specific paper and taken across campus to be dropped off.  It is a huge hassle.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Jersey City, NJ
pros: The professors' level is as good as you can expect around NY Metro Area. There is little oversight, which might be good for experienced educators and self-starters.
cons: All faculty and staff are overwhelmed with what is required of them and their workloads. As a result, there is very little involvement in the TAs activity, almost no communication and feedback. Basically you are left to fend for yourself, and there is no system in place in case there are weather-related delays or emergencies.

review_title: Great School that is on the rise and was a pleasure to work for.
job_title: Graduate Assistant in Upper Montclair, NJ
pros: Free Education, Flexible Work Schedule, Great Opportunity to Network with members of faculty.  Great Work/Life Balance
cons: Not challenging enough when it came to research and other projects.  Sometimes treated as a secretary rather than a graduate student capable of more complex tasks.

pros: State Benefits and pension, many vacation and sick days paid off, 35 hour work week.  Contribution to the community is a positive factor
cons: State position so limited pay scale and  No bonus possibility.  Limited opportunities for growth or advancement.  You have to operate under restrictive state policies and regulations which can limit work flow and production.

pros: The majority of my students are engaged and interested in the subject matter. I have a great deal of autonomy in creating my course content.
cons: I basically report to nobody. No one is checking on me, which is fine, but when I have a question, I have no idea where to go. Some of my students lack the basic skills they need to be able to succeed in classes like mine.

pros: Your experience working at Montclair State is very much contingent upon which department you work in. My department provided a wonderful environment to work in. The staff was great and very social. They have great benefits including a hefty amount of days off as you climb the career ladder there, good health insurance, and summer hours.
cons: The work itself is very repetitive and can be unenjoyable because you receive a lot of calls/emails with complaints or concerns.

job_title: Ceramic Studio Technician in San Diego, CA
pros: Great learning experience, get a better understanding of studio mechanics, great  people to work with, good atmosphere, you'll learn a lot about; fixing kilns, making clay and glazes and much more.
cons: Over worked, understaffed, bad pay

pros: This  Academic setting is a fun place to grow a career if this is your path. It is a growing campus and university full of opportunity.
cons: Budgets depend on the department and salaries can be on the lower end. Depending on the department, you may be expected to handle greater responsibility due to small staffing.

review_title: Better is out there... keep looking!
pros: Summer Fridays off, long Christmas break, nice campus
cons: Seems to be in a time warp.  Old, stodgy atmosphere.  Shady undertones... not always honest in practice... under-performing employees are tolerated... obviously in an attempt to save salary and benefits $ they give jobs to students that more experienced, polished individuals should be doing... morale is low.

pros: Close to New York City. Students tend to be very friendly and eager to learn. Diverse student body.
cons: Heavy teaching load. Limited funds to support research and travel. Cost of living is quite high relative to salary. Very much a commuter school, not much of a sense of community. Parking is a nightmare.

review_title: Student evaluations are used to evaluate teaching
pros: Some students are wonderful and I enjoy many of the staff.   There is a union for instructors that provides some protection.
cons: Research shows that there is an inverse relationship between student evaluations and learning.  Students do not like to work hard.  The university uses student evaluations to evaluate teaching, except for the occasional class visit.  Student evaluation scores on average for all professors have been going up every year, i.e., grade inflation.   There is no push back.  Students will learn less year after year if this continues.  It's a scam.

review_title: Stable, good pay, not much room for growth
pros: Campus environment, good hours (35 hours/week is f/t), good benefits, growing institution, summer work schedule (4 days/week)
cons: parking!, not much opportunity for growth, no flexible scheduling, no work from home, no development of managers, many stale employees, top leadership not very innovative.

pros: Many good people working very hard towards a common and worthwhile goal with limited resources. Spirit of camaraderie in spite of political insanity.
cons: From the top down there is a strong culture of distrust and discouragement. Little to no opportunity for advancement.  Zero morale.

pros: The University offers generally good health and retirements benefits.  The physical working environment is also generally pleasant, depending on which area of the University.
cons: Salaries are not as competitive as they are in other industries.  Also, the University doesn't offer a progressive, people-focused environment.  Professional development opportunities are rare to non-existent.

pros: The area supervisors and aquatics director are very understanding about class schedules and how sometimes their overhead management is misguided.
cons: Management shows up annually to proscribe changes which are out of sync with everyday operation; showing up late at all usually results in shaming.

pros: Close to NJ Transit and large lecture halls were modern, comfortable and fairly straightforward to teach in.
cons: Well-intentioned but frustrating bureaucracy, and lack of contact with department for which I was teaching -- no discussion of renewal of contract. What contact I had was good and helpful, I should say, but it's clear that maintaining relationships or contact with their adjuncts is just not a thing.

pros: Montclair State has a working policy for students who need work part time. Students are only allowed to work 20 hours a week which is good to give the student time for school work. Flexible scheduling is also a plus.
cons: For some residence buildings hours can be late at night which can be troublesome for students who have to take early classes.

pros: The only thing I liked about working here was my co workers who were on the same level as me, other than that it was a disaster
cons: The upper management does not care about their employees at all. They put me in an extremely uncomfortable and unacceptable situation and then tried to blame it on me. They do not care about their employees and treat them like trash.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Paltz, NY
pros: Few and far between. Projects shoved on faculty. Within easy commute to NYC arts and  culture.
cons: Enrollment micro-managers/distant/ more interested in building for show than real teaching. Image is everything- classic retailing of education- dropped SAT- reflected in student quality. Lack of respect for faculty, top heavy with administrators.

review_title: Graduate Assistantship-$7000 a year for the work of an adjunct
pros: tuition remission, small stipend, schedule around classes.
cons: Not allowed to park in faculty/staff lots so almost impossible to find parking. Extremely low pay for the work. If you work it out hourly it's far less than minimum wage. EXTREMELY strict about general chemistry lab guidelines. No flexibility in labs whatsoever.

pros: An environment filled with extensive & fun activities for faculty, staff members, & studies promoting education and services to empower need for empowerment as well as learning at the workplace
cons: Conservative & some departments are decentralized

job_title: Student Center/Front Desk/Receptionist in Paterson, NJ
pros: As a student there they are very flexible with my schedule and really nice people to work with
cons: there are no downsides working at MSU.

review_title: MICRO-MANAGES the staff to the point that you just want to quit
job_title: Customer Service II in Montclair, NJ
pros: Medical and Dental Benefits, Pension
cons: Parking is horrible. Employee lots are limited so the employees end up having to pay for parking or walking 2 miles to their office

review_title: Great... but it depends on the department
pros: I worked in the School of Business and loved it. The hours, salary, benefits and team were great. But I know that it varies greatly according to each department.
cons: High bureaucracy. Too much gossip.

pros: Beautiful campus, friendly staff, remarkable benefits, incredible salary and amazing working environment. Anyone would be lucky to get a job here.
cons: Long lines for coffee when students are on campus.

pros: Great work environment and good opportunities for development. Supervisors and managers are sympathetic and well-trained. The campus has a view of NYC and lots of greenery.
cons: It's out of the way, unless you live in Montclair. The pay could be better.

review_title: Good staff, room for growth, lots of opportunities
pros: Yearly promotions , good work environment and many opportunities for the staff including training
cons: Parking is not easy so you never know if you are going to find parking in time for work

pros: Student interaction. Great salary and benefits!!
cons: Management is very conceited and does not pay attention to the whole team.  That's not everyone, but I worked in two departments.
